I slightly messed up #21145 ; its choice of junk values for fundCircuit was bad. This is my mistake - the reason the definition was especially bad just came up in work I'm currently doing elsewhere in the repo.

This PR slightly modifies the definition of fundCircuit so that the fundamental circuit of a non-element e of the ground set is a singleton {e}, just as if {e} were a loop of M.

This removes assumptions from a couple of existing lemmas, and crucially makes the useful lemma Matroid.fundCircuit_restrict_univ true, where it wasn't before.

Out of curiosity, is the situation here that fundCircuit was being used in your repo (successfully), but it just turned out in the last couple of days that the choice that was made was suboptimal? Or is it that fundCircuit wasn't being used much, and it turned out when you came to use it that this problem was found?

It was the first. I have just started to work on representable matroids and their fundamental matrices, in which junk columns really should be zero.
I didnâ€™t realize how annoying it is that fundamental circuits for junk elements are huge meaningless sets, before the linear algebra got involved.

@Peter Nelson We recently got a little bot to respond to messages that mention a github PR like #21240 with an emoji indicating that the PR is merged/delegated/closed.
So besides writing the number in the title of the zulip thread, I encourage you to also write it in your message.

Two caveats:

  • the bot only responds to messages when something happens on github... so it will not put an emoji on this message, since the PR is already closed
  • if a message contains two PR links, then the bot will just respond with emojis for both, and we can't see which emoji belongs to which PR... c'est la vie, I guess
